pullRequest.body:
Formalize of [Popoviciu's inequality on variances](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Popoviciu%27s_inequality_on_variances)
Co-authored-by: Yuma Mizuno mizuno.y.aj@gmail.com

nodes.body:
### PR summary [f1cbc5d5be](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/17868/commits/f1cbc5d5beb41ed046b0b3cd57098202176058ce)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|

</details>

---

#### Declarations diff

`+ memâ„’p_of_bounded`
`+ variance_square_bounded`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.
Thanks for the PR!
Thanks for the PR!

That new import is unused. Please remove it.
The build failed in CI. If you click on the "details" link next to the failed build check at the bottom of this PR github page, you will get to a page that tells you why (this unused import is the reason).
Thank you for your detailed instruction. I removed the new import.

You don't need all those parentheses, and don't need to give the type of `Ï‰` each time.
```suggestion
  have h0 : 0 â‰¤ - âˆ« Ï‰, X Ï‰ ^ 2 âˆ‚Î¼ + (a + b) * âˆ« Ï‰, X Ï‰ âˆ‚Î¼ - a * b :=
```
Furthermore, you could use the notation `Î¼[X]` instead of  `âˆ« Ï‰, X Ï‰ âˆ‚Î¼`.

```suggestion
  filter_upwards [ha, hb] with Ï‰ using abs_le_max_abs_abs 
```
Thank you!
Do we really want to turn every deterministic statement ever into a statement about ae?

> Do we really want to turn every deterministic statement ever into a statement about ae?

Would it be nice to have a tactic that generates this?
It's called `filter_upwards`, as witnessed by the code
Yes indeed, but I meant something like `attribute to_ae` that generates `abs_le_max_abs_abs_ae` from `abs_le_max_abs_abs`.

Sorry, I was unclear. I mean that we do *not* want to turn every deterministic statement into an ae statement. Instead, we should use `filter_upwards` whenever needed in later proofs. Here this means *not* proving `abs_le_max_abs_abs_ae` but instead calling `filter_upwards` wherever you used `abs_le_max_abs_abs_ae`.

```suggestion

/-- ** Popoviciu's inequality on variance**

The variance of a random variable `X` satisfying `a â‰¤ X â‰¤ b`  almost everywhere is at most
`((b - a) / 2) ^ 2`. -/
```

here is a second example of parentheses and types that can be removed. Please make similar changes elsewhere.
```suggestion
      _ = âˆ« Ï‰, - X Ï‰ ^ 2 + (a + b) * X Ï‰ âˆ‚Î¼ - âˆ« _, a * b âˆ‚Î¼ :=
```
Thank you for your suggestion about parentheses. I'll revise it.

Why do you introduce a `have : âˆ€ x` to prove something for all `x`, then use it for one particular value? You could simply prove it for that value. and gain 3 lines.

Or you could extract the `have` as an independent lemma.

Thank you for pointing that out.
I wasn't able to clean up the code completely.

Having those two counditions for ae bounded seems a bit verbose. What about this:
```suggestion
theorem memâ„’p_of_mem_Icc [IsFiniteMeasure Î¼]
    {a b : â„} {X : Î© â†’ â„} (h : âˆ€áµ Ï‰ âˆ‚Î¼, X Ï‰ âˆˆ Icc a b)
    (hX : AEMeasurable X Î¼) (p : ENNReal) : Memâ„’p X p Î¼ :=
```
Also that lemma should be moved to another file. `#find_home!` is useful to find a good file.

> Having those two counditions for ae bounded seems a bit verbose. What about this:

I realized two bounded conditions are verbose, but I was not sure which way is the most clear, so thank you for telling me the answer.

> Also that lemma should be moved to another file. `#find_home!` is useful to find a good file.

I moved memâ„’p_of_mem_Icc to Mathlib.MeasureTheory.Function.LpSeminorm.Basic file and added the import.

```suggestion
    (memâ„’p_of_bounded h hX.aestronglyMeasurable 2).integrable_sq.neg
```

Can you deduce this from the [Bhatia-Davis inequality](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bhatia%E2%80%93Davis_inequality)? It can be stated as
```
/-- **The Bhatia-Davis inequality on variance**

The variance of a random variable `X` satisfying `a â‰¤ X â‰¤ b`  almost everywhere is at most
`(b - ð”¼ X) * (ð”¼ X - a)`. -/
lemma variance_le_sub_mul_sub [IsProbabilityMeasure Î¼] {a b : â„} {X : Î© â†’ â„}
    (h : âˆ€áµ Ï‰ âˆ‚Î¼, X Ï‰ âˆˆ Set.Icc a b) (hX : AEMeasurable X Î¼) :
    variance X Î¼ â‰¤ (b - Î¼[X]) * (Î¼[X] - a) :=
```

```suggestion
/-- **Popoviciu's inequality on variance**
```

pullRequest.title: feat: Popoviciu's inequality
